    Glutaminyl Cyclase, Diseases, and Development of Glutaminyl Cyclase Inhibitors

    • Chenshu Xu
      Chenshu Xu
      School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Health Science Center, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, China
      More by Chenshu Xu
      View Biography
      https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8799-1913
      • , 
    • Yi-nan Wang
      Yi-nan Wang
      School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Health Science Center, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, China
      More by Yi-nan Wang
      View Biography
      • , and 
    • Haiqiang Wu*
      Haiqiang Wu
      School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Health Science Center, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, China
      *[email protected]
      More by Haiqiang Wu

    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2021, 64, 10, 6549–6565

    SUBJECTS:
    • Rodent models,
    • Inhibitors,
    • Peptides and proteins,
    • Central nervous system,
    • Inflammation
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Pyroglutamate (pE) modification, catalyzed mainly by glutaminyl cyclase (QC), is prevalent throughout nature and is particularly important in mammals including humans for the maturation of hormones, peptides, and proteins. In humans, the upregulation of QC is involved in multiple diseases and conditions including Alzheimer’s disease, Huntington’s disease, melanomas, thyroid carcinomas, accelerated atherosclerosis, septic arthritics, etc. This upregulation catalyzes the generation of modified mediators such as pE-amyloid beta (Aß) and pE-chemokine ligand 2 (CCL2) peptides. Not surprisingly, QC has emerged as a reasonable target for the development of therapeutics to combat these diseases and conditions. In this manuscript the deleterious effects of upregulated QC resulting in disease manifestation are reviewed, along with progress on the development of QC inhibitors.

    1. Glutaminyl Cyclase

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    1.1. Introduction

    In 1963, the first glutaminyl cyclase (QC, also known as glutaminyl-peptide cyclotransferase, QPCT, EC 2.3.2.5) was isolated form the latex of a tropical plant (Carica papaya).(1,2) Since then, proteins catalyzing the same reaction have been identified and isolated from a wide range of pro- and eukaryotes. For example, these proteins, with molecular weights ranging between 33 and 40 kDa, have been identified in rat brain, porcine pituitary, bovine pituitary and spleen, human B lymphocytes, snake venom, bacterial pathogens, and even recently in cone snails.(3−7) QCs from different species exhibit overlapping but distinct homologies, structure, and characteristics.(3,8−11) The similarity in amino acid sequence, for instance, between the QC from the plant bacterial pathogen Xanthomonas campestris and the host plant is ∼20–30%,(7) whereas the similarity in the amino acid sequence between QCs isolated from snake and human is ∼75%.(4) The specificity constraints of QCs are dependent on the size and composition of the substrates. All these proteins catalyze the formation of pyroglutamate (pE)-modified peptides and proteins. QCs from plants also catalyze the cyclization of a methylated glutamine residue, while human QCs mainly catalyze the cyclization of N-terminal glutamate/glutamine.(12)
    Noteworthy, mammalian glutaminyl cyclase isoenzymes (iso-QCs) were identified in 2008, including human iso-QC and murine iso-QC.(13) QC, which is secreted by secretory granules into the neuronal extracellular space, and iso-QC, which is localized within the Golgi complex, are encoded by different genes in humans. The gene encoding QC is located on chromosome 2p22.3, and the gene encoding iso-QC is located on chromosome 19q13.32.(13−15) As shown in Figure 1, human QC is composed of 361 amino acids and possesses an N-terminal secretion signal, whereas iso-QC is composed of 382 amino acids and carries an N-terminal signal anchor. Both QC and iso-QC, however, contain catalytic domains of similar size (∼330 residues) and share a sequence identity of ∼45%. Both QC and iso-QC catalyze the N-terminal pE modification, but iso-QC exhibits 2- to 15-fold less catalytic activity with several synthetic substrates compared with that of QC. Furthermore, the expression of QC is higher in neuronal tissues, whereas the expression of iso-QC shows no significant difference between different tissues and organs. In nine different mouse strains, the highest enzymatic QC/iso-QC activity is in the ventral brain, followed by the cortex and hippocampus.(16) The QC knockout (KO) dramatically reduces the QC activity in the mouse brain, especially in the hypothalamus and plasma, although activity is still detectable in peripheral organs such as the liver and spleen, which is likely the result of the expression of iso-QC.(17) In the KO mouse serum, the concentration of a gonadotropin-releasing hormone and testosterone are not changed, but the serum thyroxine is slightly decreased. The adult KO mice are fertile and behave indistinguishably from the wild-type mice, indicating the potential therapeutic effect for drug development by inhibiting QC activity.
    The sequence identity between human QC and iso-QC is 45%. The residues involved in zinc complexation in the active site (Asp-Glu-His) are conserved in both proteins. Iso-QC possesses two potential start methionine residues designated as Met I and Met II. The major differences between these two sequences are at the N-terminus. QC possesses a signal sequence directing the protein to the secretory pathway, whereas iso-QC carries a putative signal anchor. Moreover, iso-QC lacks N-glycosylation sites, while two such sites are identified in QC.(18)
    A variety of methods has been developed to measure the enzymatic activity of QC and iso-QC, including isocratic reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography with fluorometric detection, which monitors the formation of pGlu-Leu-Tyr-Glu-Asn-Lys-epsilon-(Dns)–OH chromatographically separated from the fluorescent substrate Gln-Leu-Tyr-Glu-Asn-Lys-epsilon-(Dns)–OH.(19) Radioimmunoassay is also used to detect the formation of pyroGlu-His-Pro-NH2 from a thyrotropin-releasing hormone substrate.(20) Other methods include coupled enzymatic assays to detect the release of ammonia from the cyclization of the Gln-Gln dipeptide substrate and UV adsorption to detect the change induced by the formation of an intramolecular amide bond during pE modification.(10,19−23) Coupled continuous assays, which use pyroglutamyl aminopeptidase or glutamate dehydrogenase as auxiliary enzymes, are also widely applied by determining the release of chromophores or fluorophores and the conversion of NADH/H+ into NAD+.(24)

    1.2. The Structure of QC

    On the basis of the homology analysis, human QC (hQC) shares certain similarities with an exopeptidase family, which includes Aeromonas proteolytica aminopeptidase (ApAP), Streptomyces griseus aminopeptidase (SgAP), and carboxypeptidase G2 (CPG2). All these proteins share a conserved scaffold with hQC but differ in structure particularly in the loops surrounding the active-site pockets. As a one-zinc ion-dependent monomeric glycoprotein, hQC is composed of a signal peptide containing 27 or 28 amino acid residues, a positively charged N-terminal region, a central hydrophobic region containing 10 amino acid residues, and a C-terminal region containing a critical nonpolar amino acid residue (Ser27 or Gly28).(25) The signal peptide plays a key role in the transportation of immature QC from ribosomes to the endoplasmic reticulum to complete the folding of the polypeptide chain, including the formation of six β-sheets and 10 α-helices, glycosylation of Asp46 and 296, and the formation of a disulfide bond between Cys139 and 149.(11,13) This signal peptide also contributes to the transportation of QC to the target secretory granules.
    The catalytic domain of hQC is composed of ∼330 residues. The high-resolution crystal structure of hQC residues 33–361 from bone marrow exhibits an open-sandwich topology comprising a central six-stranded β-sheet surrounded by two and six α-helices on the opposite sides and flanked by two α-helices at one edge of the β-sheet (Figure 2A).(26) The twisted β-sheet is formed by two antiparallel and four parallel strands, acting as the hydrophobic core of the molecule. The coil and loop regions of the structure cover 42% of the total residues, and approximately half of these regions contribute to the formation of the active site, in which six loops between these surrounded α-helices are near the C-terminal edge of the central parallel strands. The lone Zn2+ ion is located at the bottom of the narrow hydrophobic pocket near Asp159, Glu202, and His330 (Figure 2B). To maintain the catalytic activity, it is important to coordinate the Zn2+ with residues Glu201, Trp207, Asp248, Asp305, Phe325, and Trp329, hydrogen bonds between Glu201, Asp248, and Asp305, and a peptide bond between Asp159 and Ser160, which is further stabilized by hydrogen bonds Asp159-His140, Ser160-Asp248, Asp159-water, and Ser160-water. Iso-QC is also a one-zinc ion-dependent cyclase. Compared with hQC, the crystal structure of iso-QC demonstrates a relatively wide-open and negatively charged active site with a large loop movement in the active site upon inhibitor binding (Figure 2C).(27) The lone zinc ion is also located at the bottom of the pocket by Asp186, Glu226, and His351 (Figure 2D).
    The structures of other mammalian and insect QCs exhibit high degrees of similarity with that of hQC, in which the main core of the tertiary structure is formed by a central six-stranded β-sheet surrounded by several α-helices. The structure of N-glycosylated QC from human and mouse is stabilized by the disulfide bond between the two conserved cysteine residues at the bottom of the pocket and the two surface loops near the active site.(28) The conserved tryptophan residue Trp207, which lies at the entrance of the active site, shows a single conformation in both N-glycosylated human and murine QCs and affects substrate conversion significantly.(28) QC from Drosophila melanogaster (fruit fly) has an overall fold similar to that of mammalian QCs.(29) However, plant and bacterial QCs adopt a five-bladed β-propeller fold, and the biological functions of these QCs have not been elucidated until recently.(9,28) Ligand-free QC from Drosophila melanogaster exhibits a typical α/β-hydrolase topology, which is different from the structure of QC when binding with inhibitors, and this form of QC would be helpful for the structural studies of novel inhibitor-binding modes.(30)
    A metal-independent QC has been identified from the black-legged tick Ixodes scapularis.(31) Interestingly, the crystal structure demonstrated the typical scaffold of mammalian QCs but with two extra disulfide bonds to stabilize the central β-sheet. The catalytic activity can be inhibited by imidazole-derived inhibitors designed for the Zn2+-dependent QC.

    1.3. pE-Modification in the Pocket of QC

    N-Terminal pE in mammals is required for the maturation and/or function of newly formed peptides, hormones, cytokines, and proteins in the secretory pathway. The pE modifications appear to be important for a proper conformation for binding with receptors and/or to protect the N termini from exopeptidase degradation.(32,33) pE modification also improves the functions of peptides; for example, pE-serpinin, which is derived from chromogranin A (CgA) and identified in secretory granules of endocrine and neuro-endocrine cells, exhibits antiapoptotic effects.(34) The presence of pE could also enhance the stability and strengthen the activity of recombinant proteins, such as cellulose Cel7A.(35,36)
    The N-terminal glutamine and/or glutamate is cyclized to pyroglutamate in the presence of phosphate ions by facilitating synchronized proton transfers.(37) As an important post-translational or cotranslational event, N-terminal pE modification was previously thought to proceed spontaneously. However, it has been demonstrated recently that QC mainly catalyzes the conversion of the N-terminal glutamine (Glu, Q) residue and glutamate to pyroglutamate (pE) in vitro and in vivo.(8,37−39) Compared with the nonenzymatic catalysis, QC accelerates the pE-modification by promoting a synchronized proton transfer in a concerted four-step mechanism: (A) Zn2+ polarizes the γ-amido carbonyl of the substrate based on the cation–anion interaction between Zn2+ and oxygen; (B) Zn2+ stabilizes the oxygen ions that resulted from the electrophilic attack by the positively charged α-amino group; (C) a proton is transferred to the γ-amide through the assistance of Glu201; (D) Asp248 improves the leaving of γ-amide amino in the presence of H2O (Figure 3).(14,40) Positively charged Zn2+ acts as the key mediator for the conversion, and the central triad formed by Glu201-Asp305-Asp248 is necessary for the catalytic activity. Consequently, proton transfer(s) have been assigned as the rate-limiting step.
    It is confirmed that the conversions of Glu and Gln are favored at pH 6.0 and 8.0, respectively.(39) The conformations of Asp248 and Asp305 are affected by Ser160 and His319, respectively, indicating the importance of proton transfer between Glu201, Asp305, and Asp248.(41) Furthermore, the mutation of His140 and His330 into glutamic acid results in the loss of activity. In contrast, the mutation of His307 and His319 into glutamic acid significantly increases the Michaelis–Menten constant (Km) of QC.(42) This observation demonstrated that His140 and His330 are directly involved in the catalysis, while His307 and His319 are involved in substrate recognition. Disulfide bonds between cysteine residues are also important for the maintenance of protein conformation and activity, which is broken by treatment with 15 mM dithiothreitol (DTT).(11) These results directly and indirectly support the catalyzing process in the QC active pocket.

    2. Upregulated QC and Diseases

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Under normal conditions, pE modification at the N-termini mediated by QC or iso-QC is necessary for the maturation and physiological activity of newly formed peptides, hormones, cytokines, and proteins. However, an abnormal upregulation of QC or iso-QC and excessive pyroglutamination are hallmarks of multiple diseases and conditions involving neurodegeneration, inflammation, uncontrolled cell division, and others, by catalyzing the generation of excessive levels of pE-modified mediators (Figure 4).

    2.1. Neurodegenerative Diseases

    Mounting evidence confirms that the post-translational pE modification catalyzed by QC could be supposed as a crucial pathological mechanism leading to increased aggregation and enhanced toxicity of amyloid peptides in a number of degenerative diseases. Neurodegenerative diseases include Alzheimer’s (AD), Parkinson’s (PD), Huntington’s (HD), etc. AD, characterized by a gradual decline in learning and memory ability, is the most common of these and accounts for more than 65% of total neurodegenerative cases. With the increasing number of aging population worldwide, the health, economic, and social impact of AD is expected to rise significantly. While progress is being made to understand the pathogenesis, there are still no treatments for AD that can cure or halt the progression of the disease.
    As one of the major pathological hallmarks, senile plaques composed of β-amyloid (Aβ) peptides were previously thought to be the main cause of AD. However, there is no direct correlation between the formation of senile plaques in brains and the development of AD. On the contrary, it has now been demonstrated that pE-modified Aβs, for example, pE-Aβ3–40 and pE-Aβ3–42, are the main components of senile plaques.(43−45) These pE-modified Aβs account for more than 50% of total Aβ plaques in AD brains and are absent in matching normal brains. Aβs truncated at the N-terminal position 3 (AβpN3) are also detected in canine brains in a concentration/age-dependent manner, and in other animal species as well, such as Japanese macaque, American black bear, and woodpecker.(46) pE modification increases the hydrophobicity, changes the pH-dependent solubility profiles of Aβs, and results in different biochemical and biophysical properties of Aβs.(47) Compared with Aβ, pE-Aβs aggregate more rapidly, confer enhanced stability and proteolytic resistance, and seed further Aβ aggregation. For instance, pE-Aβ co-oligomerizes with excess Aβs and forms oligomers that are structurally distinct and more cytotoxic than oligomers made from Aβs alone. Structural and conformational features of small, medium, and large aggregates of pE-Aβ are different from that of Aβ.(48) As a result, pE-Aβs exhibit greater neurotoxicity and contribute to the dysfunction of neurons and initiation of AD (Figure 5).(43,48−54)
    Because of the enhanced hydrophobicity, pE-Aβ peptides bind to and are more toxic to neurons than Aβ peptides.(55) In neurons, pE-Aβs induce lipid peroxidation, trigger Ca2+ influx, and cause the loss of plasma membrane integrity. Abnormally generated pE-Aβs exhibit neuron toxicity in a number of transgenic murine AD models. These models include 5XFAD mice, which coexpress five familial AD mutations, and 5XFAD/hQC and ETNA (E at the truncated N-terminus of Aβ) mice, which express truncated human Aβ3–42 and ETNA-hQC, respectively.(54,56,57) More importantly, the level of IgM autoantibodies against pE-Aβ correlates with the cognitive decline in human AD.(58)
    In a post-mortem human brain, pE-Aβ aggregates mainly accumulate in the lysosomes of both neurons and glia cells and increase in an age-dependent manner.(59) The cytotoxicity of pE-Aβ is tau protein and/or hyperphosphorylated tau protein dependent, and the influence of pE-Aβ aggregated in the frontal cortex on both the severity of AD neuropathology and clinical symptoms of dementia is confirmed in humans.(60,61) Interestingly, active and passive immunization targeting pE-Aβs exhibits remarkable effects on reducing plaques and improving cognitive potency in a murine AD model.(62−64) Therefore, the generation of pE-Aβs is now confirmed as a key inducer in the initiation of AD and plays a crucial role in the development of the disease.(65−69)
    It is now appreciated that the deposition of pE-Aβs in the hippocampus, piriform cortex, and amygdala is accompanied by the endogenous expression of QC in APP-transgenic Tg2576 mice expressing human APP.(68) The dependence of pE-Aβ generation on QC was observed in transgenic TBA2.1 and TBA2.2 mice with truncated mutant human Aβ, APP-transgenic Tg2576 mice with human APP, 5XFAD/hQC bigenic AD mice, and transgenic ETNA and double transgenic ETNA-hQC mice.(54,56,57,70) pE-Aβs, QC, and Aβs along with certain neuropeptides and catecholamines were also identified in isolated dense core secretory vesicles (DCSV), and cosecretion of cellular pE-Aβs and QC with Aβs, enkephalin, and galanin was inhibited in the presence of the QC inhibitor, PQ529.(71) The generation of pE in rat cortex was inhibited significantly by an intracortical microinjection of PBD150, another QC inhibitor.(72) More importantly, in AD patients, QC was overexpressed by urocortin-1 and cholinergic Edinger-Westphal neurons, and by locus coeruleus and nucleus basalis Meynert neurons in subcortical brain.(73) The intraneuronal pE-Aβ immunoreactivity, a morphological sign of degeneration, and extracellular pE-Aβ deposits were displayed in these neuronal populations. These observations indicated the involvement of upregulated QC in the initiation of AD by catalyzing the generation of pE-Aβ peptides. Positive correlations between the QC mRNA levels and the amount of pE-Aβ aggregates, but not Aβ, in human post-mortem brain further addressed the role of QC in AD.(74) Upregulated QC also induces the regulation of Aβ38, Aβ40, and angiogenesis mediators such as Flt1, Tie2, VEGFD, VCAM-1, and ICAM-1 in AD patients.(75)
    Although the causes inducing the upregulation of QC are not clear, evidence is accumulating to reveal the underlying mechanism. For instance, it has been demonstrated that perturbed intracellular Ca2+ homeostasis induces the upregulation of QC in vitro because of a putative binding site for the Ca2+-dependent transcription factors c-fos and c-jun contained within the QC promoter.(76) Besides, the levels of QC mRNA, together with those of BACE1 and cathepsin B, were significantly upregulated in mouse brain after a transient global cerebral ischemia, which may contribute to the understanding of the relationship between cerebral ischemia and AD.(77) Note that the levels of QC mRNA and QC protein were higher in peripheral blood from AD patients than those in blood from age-matched controls, and the expression of QC was positively correlated with the severity of dementia.(78) QC activity in human cerebrospinal fluid and levels of mRNA and protein in peripheral blood could be supposed as new biomarkers for the clinical diagnosis of AD.(78,79) As a conclusion, considering the positive correlation between the activity of QC and the development of AD, the upregulation of QC is now considered by many as a crucial pathological signal in the initiation of AD at an early stage and as a reasonable target for the discovery of novel anti-AD agents.
    HD is a neurodegenerative disease caused by an expanded CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the gene encoding for Huntington (HTT) protein and characterized by a combination of motor, cognitive, and behavioral features.(80,81) Small interfering RNA (siRNA) screening of human cells demonstrated that upregulated QC enhances the neurotoxicity induced by the trinucleotide repeats and plays crucial roles in the development of HD in a Drosophila model, although the details of the mechanism need to be further studied.(82)
    Familial British dementia (FBD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder.(83) The accumulation of amyloid Bri (ABri), another amyloidogenic fragment resulting from the abnormal stop of an Arg mutation in the BRI gene, was detected in FBD brains. pE-modified ABri and amyloid-Dan (ADan), another amyloid peptide cleaved in familial Danish dementia (FDD), were present in extracellular plaques, vascular, and parenchymal deposits in human FBD and FDD brains, respectively.(84) Besides, ABri1–34pE takes a large proportion in water- and formic acid-soluble ABri molecules extracted from FBD brains, and in soluble and fibrillary ABri molecules extracted from systemic organs such as uterus, skeletal muscles, and pancreas.(85) These results indicated that pE-modified inducers also contribute to the initiation of FBD and FDD, and pE modification at the N-terminal of ABri and ADan is performed at the beginning of FBD and FDD amyloid deposition.(85,86)

    2.2. Inflammation

    Compared with the contribution of upregulated QC to the development of neurodegenerative diseases, the upregulation of iso-QC appears to trigger inflammatory reactions mainly by pE-modifying the CC chemokine ligand 2 (CCL2, also known as monocyte chemoattractant protein-1, MCP-1).(16,87−89) Produced by Aβ-stimulated microglia and astrocytes and a variety of immune cells, CCL2 deficiency results in accelerated β-amyloidosis, reduced neurogenesis in the dentate gyrus of hippocampus, and consequently memory impairment.(90) In contrast, patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) in which CCL2 expression is upregulated in the frontal cortex, are at high risk for developing AD.(91) The level of CCL2 in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is positively correlated with a faster cognitive decline in patients with prodromal AD, and there is a correlation between the plasma CCL2 concentrations and the severity of traumatic brain injury (TBI).(91−93) Therefore, in addition to tau, p-tau, and Aβ, CSF CCL2 could also be applied as a potential biomarker to predict the rate of cognitive decline and the conversion of prodromal AD to AD.
    Usually, CCL2 induces chemotaxis of monocytes and microglia through binding with chemokine receptor CCR2, a seven transmembrane spanning Gαi protein-coupled receptor constitutively expressed on monocytes and macrophages.(94,95) By the mobilization of bone marrow monocytes and the recruitment of monocytes to sites of infection and inflammation, the CCL2-CCR2 pathway plays a pivotal role in acute and chronic inflammatory disorders and related diseases such as atherosclerosis, fibrosis, and AD.(96−101) Considering the regulations involved in innate immune reactions, the CCL2-CCR2 pathway is suggested as a potential target for the therapeutics of inflammatory diseases.(102,103)
    Research has further demonstrated that an intact N-terminus is necessary for CCL2 to activate CCR2, and the N-terminus is more susceptible to degradation by aminopeptidases such as DPP-4.(104,105) CCL2, with an artificial elongation or truncation, loses the ability to recruit circulating monocytes to the sites of infection and inflammation. Interestingly, the N-terminus of human CCL2 is predominantly cyclized, and the levels of pE-CCL2 are higher than those of CCL2 in inflammatory reactions. pE modification significantly enhances the hydrophobicity of CCL2, and this in turn improves the interaction between CCL2 and CCR2.(32,106,107) Compared with CCL2, pE-CCL2 is a stronger CCR2 ligand and more active in chemotaxis assays, displaying a higher functional activity. Meanwhile, the presence of pE confers resistance to degradation and significantly increases the in vivo half-life of CCL2. As a result, inflammatory reactions are overactivated.
    It has been confirmed in vitro that the generation of pE-CCL2 is catalyzed by both QC and iso-QC. However, iso-QC mainly contributes to the pE-CCL2 formation, monocyte infiltration, and CCL2-driven inflammation in vivo.(87,88,108) Considering the roles of iso-QC/QC in monocyte infiltration in inflammatory conditions, the positive correlation between the upregulation of QC, generation of pE-CCL2, and development of inflammation might support the discovery of novel agents for the treatment of inflammatory diseases such as septic arthritis induced by Staphylococcus aureus by inhibiting QC activity (Figure 6).(109−111)
    CX3CL1, also known as fractalkine, is another mediator for the attraction and migration of monocytes in inflammatory processes.(112,113) CX3CL1 mediates the integrin-independent adhesion by binding with CX3CR1 (fractalkine receptor 1).(114,115) On the basis of the regulation of leucocyte recruitment and intercellular communication, the CX3CL1-CX3CR1 pathway exhibits the necessary potency to spark the initiation and development of inflammation.(115) Similar to CCL2, there is a glutamine at the N-terminus of CX3CL1, which could be pE post-translationally modified by both QC and iso-QC. Furthermore, pE is required for CX3CL1 to activate other pathways such as ERK1/2, p38, and Akt kinases.(116) These results further support the role for iso-QC/QC in inflammatory processes.

    2.3. Cancer and Other Diseases

    In addition to neurodegenerative diseases and inflammation, abnormally upregulated QC/iso-QC might act as the main cause of thyroid carcinomas. Compared to the expression in goiter tissues, the expression of QC, not iso-QC, in tissues of patients was upregulated significantly and positively correlated with the level of CCL2, and all CCL2 were secreted as pE-CCL2 in the supernatant of thyroid cancer cells.(117) The increased functional activity of CCL2 triggers the development of thyroid carcinomas by recruiting monocytes/macrophages to the sites of inflammation.
    CD47, a transmembrane protein ligand for myeloid cells, is overexpressed in various cancers and exhibits potency in the development of these cancers. The binding of CD47 to signal regulatory protein alpha (SIRPα) protects cancer cells from phagocytosis by forming the “don’t eat me” signal.(118) Gln19 at the N-terminus of CD47 could be modified to pE by iso-QC in vitro, and the presence of pE contributed to the binding of CD47 to SIRPα more efficiently.(119,120) Therefore, iso-QC is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cancers through the regulation of the CD47-SIRPα axis.
    On the basis of Principal Components Analyses with 90 cancer cell lines from three microarray data sets, a defined melanoma component is identified that contains a gene coding for the highly expressed QC.(121) QC may interfere with the tumor destructive process of vaccines using peptides carrying glutamine or glutamic acid at their N-termini. So, the inhibition of QC activity may improve the efficacy of the melanoma vaccine. Interestingly, the QPCT gene is methylated in more than 95% of uncultured melanoma tumor samples.(121,122)
    Analysis of genotypes or haplotypes in 384 Japanese adult women with low radical bone mineral density (BMD) indicated that the genetic variations in QC mainly contributed to the susceptibility to osteoporosis by modifying peptide hormones, for example, GnRH.(123) Gene expression profiling of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) in 29 patients with rheumatoid arthritis and 21 controls demonstrated that the abnormal expression of QC might also be involved in the development of rheumatoid arthritis.(124)
    QCs from the oral pathogens Porphyromonas gingivalis, Tannerella forsythia, and Prevotella intermedia represent attractive target enzymes for small-molecule inhibitor development. These QCs possess sequences corresponding to type II QCs, observed hitherto only in animals, and exhibit comparable catalytic efficiencies and are inhibited by metal chelators. Crystal structures of these QCs reveal a tertiary structure composed of an eight-stranded β-sheet surrounded by seven α-helices, and an active site Zn ion is tetrahedrally coordinated by conserved residues. These studies indicate that mammalian-type QC from certain pathogens is also a potential drug target for the treatment of periodontitis and associated diseases.(125)

    3. Discovery and Development of QC Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Considering the widespread and pervasive homeostatic consequences of upregulated QC, reducing the generation of pE-modified mediators by inhibiting QC may be a novel approach to the prevention and treatment of diseases including AD, inflammation, and cancer. In the past decades, a series of compounds has been developed and determined as QC inhibitors.(126,127)

    3.1. Imidazole-Containing Chemicals

    In 1987 it was reported that, in vivo, the post-translational conversion of a glutaminyl-peptide into a pyroglutamyl-peptide is mainly catalyzed by QC based on an assay measuring the rate of conversion of Gln-His-Pro-NH2 to pyroGlu-His-Pro-NH2 (TRH).(20) Then, it was shown that the activity of hQC is reduced by 1,10-phenanthroline and dipicolinic acid in a time-dependent inhibition manner, thus identifying imidazole and imidazole derivatives as competitive QC inhibitors. These metal chelators inhibit the activity, which is reversed by the addition of Zn2+, and the addition of other metal ions such as Co2+ and Mn2+ partially reactivate the activity.(14) Together, hQC was revealed as a metal-dependent enzyme based on the pH-dependent inhibition by imidazole derivatives and the kinetic parameter Km of the QC-catalyzed conversion.(14)
    Bidentate heterocyclic compounds have the ability to bind with most metal ions to form stable coordinated complexes. However, these agents also trigger the destruction of multiple biochemical reactions in vivo because of their potency and promiscuous binding affinities. To discover new QC inhibitors, many phenanthroline-type heterocyclic compounds, including five- and six-membered ring systems, have been screened for QC inhibition. Imidazole and its derivatives are more potent than others (Figure 7). A structure–activity relationship (SAR) analysis indicated that imidazole is the important motif to inhibit the activity of QC, and it does so by binding to the Zn2+ located at the bottom of the pocket.(128) Modifications of the imidazole moiety significantly affect the inhibitory potency. Methylation and benzylation of the nitrogen atom at position 1 of imidazole resulted in a 3- and 14-fold potency increase, respectively. However, the introduction of phenylalanine at the same position significantly lowered the potency, and phenylation of the same position and methylation of the carbon atom at position 2 also reduced the inhibitory potency.(128)
    To improve potency and specificity, a ligand-based optimization approach has been employed. On the basis of the screening of designed thiourea derivatives, imidazole-1-yl-alkyl thiourea was developed as a leading scaffold, and 1-(3-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)propyl)-3-(3,4-dimethoxyphenyl) thiourea (53, also named as PBD150, Ki = 0.06 ± 0.0002 μM, Figure 7) proved to be a potent inhibitor. According to a docking analysis, Zn2+ could be coordinated by imidazole. The donor nitrogen of the thiourea is found to form the essential H bond. The phenyl part of the inhibitor fits the hydrophobic pocket. And the methoxy substituents on the aromatic motif exhibit a big impact on the inhibitory bonding.(128) Subsequently, imidazole-propyl-thioamides were demonstrated as another class of potential inhibitors carrying the same scaffold, such as compound 2, Ki = 0.09 ± 0.0002 μM (Figure 7).(128) The site-directed mutagenesis of hQC has also been used to explore the detailed specific interactions between test compounds and QC. Replacing the alanine or asparagine of hQC with F325 and I303 resulted in an 800-fold decrease in the inhibitory activity of PBD150. In contrast, exchanging S323 with alanine or valine resulted in a 20-fold increase in the inhibitory activity of the same compound.(129) This result further confirmed the binding of imidazole to Zn2+ in the active pocket as shown in the proposed docking model.
    A homology model of QC was developed to support the discovery of new QC inhibitors. Replacements of thiourea with cyanoguanidine or nitrovinyldiamine exhibited no significant effect on potency. However, the replacement of 3,4-dimethoxyphenyl with saturated carbocyclic substituents exhibited a slight positive effect, partly because of the different binding mode. Incorporation of thiourea into thioxopyrimidine was helpful for increasing the potency in the presence of the favored annulated saturated ring. Interestingly, compared with their corresponding 4-methylimidazole analogues, 5-methylimidazole thioureas, cyanoguanidines, nitrovinyldiamines, and thioxopyrinidines exhibited an improvement on the inhibitory potency; for example, the introduction of a methyl at position 5 resulted in an elevation of 10- and 35-fold for compounds 9 (Ki = 6.3 ± 0.45 nM) and 11 (Ki = 2.6 ± 0.08 nM, Figure 7), in comparison to PBD150, respectively.(130) Compared to other parts of these compounds, the binding of 5-methylimidazole with the Zn2+ exhibits a higher inhibitory effect.
    Another series of compounds has been prepared in which benzimidazole connected to 1,3,4-oxadiazole was presented as the metal binding motif. A pharmacophore-based screen confirmed the potency of this novel scaffold. Among them, 8h (Ki = 23 ± 1 nM, Figure 7) exhibited potent QC inhibitory activity.(131) Considering the docking mode of the preferred substrate with QC and the structure of PBD150, heterocycles were introduced to the aromatic moiety region in N-aryl-N-(5-methyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl) propyl thioureas. The half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) value of compound 52 (Figure 7) was 58 nM, showing an improvement of more than twofold in comparison to that of PBD150.(132)
    Interestingly, PQ912 ([(S)-1-(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-5-yl)-5-(4-propoxyphenyl)imidazolidin-2-one], Ki = 24.6 ± 0.7 nM, Figure 7) was reported as a new QC inhibitor.(133−135) Different from the scaffolds mentioned above, benzoimidazol, presented as Zn2+ binding motif at position 1 of imidazolidine-2-one, is located near to an o-substituted 4-propoxyphenyl at position 5. The development of PQ912, which is the first QC inhibitor undergoing a clinical trial against AD, will hopefully lead to the discovery of novel and clinically effective QC inhibitors.
    To discover novel scaffolds, a series of diphenyl conjugated imidazole derivatives (DPCIs) have been prepared, guided by rational design based on the crystal structure of hQC.(136) To reduce the flexibility and improve the blood-brain barrier (BBB) penetrability, a diphenyl moiety was generated by introducing one more phenyl ring to the phenyl motif and an imidazole functional linker at the ortho position of the new phenyl ring. Analogues exhibited remarkable QC inhibitory activity, and anti-AD potency is expected, for example, compound 28 (IC50 = 1.23 μM, Figure 7). The chelation between the imidazole ring and Zn2+ at the bottom of the pocket was conserved, which contributed to the improved BBB penetration and potency of these agents. In addition to the enhanced inflexibility of the molecule induced by the middle aromatic motif, the π–π stacking between the terminal aromatic motif and Phe325 at the hydrophobic entrance also contributed to the improved BBB penetration and potency of these agents.
    According to the binding mode of pE-Aβ3–42 in the pocket of QC, another scaffold was designed based on the structure of PBD150. A series of motifs was added to mimic the guanidine moiety of Arg contained in Aβ3–42, the enhanced potency of which was confirmed. This included a 5–40-fold increase compared to that of PBD150. Particularly, compound 212 (IC50 = 4.5 ± 1.4 nM, Figure 7) reduced the generation of pE-Aβ and total Aβ and restored cognitive functions in AD mice.(137) The potency improvement was thought to result from the strong interaction between the compound and the carboxylic acid group of Glu327 at the active site.(31) This scaffold was developed further to improve the potency and BBB penetration by replacing the linker with different Arg mimetic groups that could form an additional hydrophobic interaction in the pocket. Compound 202 was shown as a potential candidate with an IC50 of 6.2 ± 2.9 nM.(138) In the following research, 3-aminoalkyloxy-4-methoxyphenyl and 4-aminoalkyloxyphenyl groups were introduced as Arg-mimetic pharmacophores. Treatment of compound 53 reduced the generation of pE-Aβ3–40 significantly in acute AD mice with reasonable BBB penetration and low cytotoxicity.(139) The slat bridge interaction and hydrogen bonding of the protonated amine group with Glu327 and Pro326 were thought to contribute to the potency of these molecules.
    SEN177 (Figure 7), a designed compound composed of a triazine ring as the hQC-binding motif, exhibited remarkable hQC inhibitory potency (Ki = 20 nM).(140) This molecule has already shown interesting pharmacological properties against HTT aggregation. Together with the peculiar-binding mode, this new scaffold may provide clues to the discovery of new high-affinity QC inhibitors targeting AD.
    A series of N-substituted thiourea/urea analogues of compound 9 was prepared based on a rigidification strategy, and different alkyl groups and aromatic and heteroaromatic functional groups were introduced to generate the bent conformation of 9. SAR analyses indicated that these conformationally restrained compounds had improved QC inhibitory potency, and the Z-E conformation of the compound at the active site was critical for activity. For example, compound 90 (IC50 = 6.1 nM, Figure 7) showed promising efficacy and significantly reduced the brain concentrations of pE-Aβ and total Aβ in the 5XFAD mouse model.(141)
    Related studies have pushed the discovery of yet other novel QC inhibitors. For instance, a small molecule, 1, was synthesized, which exhibited an IC50 value of 5.11 μM (Figure 7).(142) A comparative molecular field analysis (CoMFA) of 50 imidazole derivatives demonstrated that a benzene ring at the para- and meta-positions improved the inhibitory potency.(143) Two-dimensional-autocorrelation (2D AUTO) and atom-centered fragment (ACF) descriptors were prepared to aid the design of new molecules.(144) Fragment-based drug discovery has also been applied in the development of novel QC inhibitors through the preparation of a QC fragment library, screening of lead compounds in the library in vitro, and performing binding interaction analysis.(145) Through a pharmacophore-assisted high-throughput virtual screening, piperidine-4-carboxamide was indicated as a new scaffold for the development of QC inhibitors based on the unique binding model at the active site of QC.(146)
    The conclusions drawn from the above-mentioned information are that QC inhibitory potency requires two predominant features: (1) a Zn2+ binding motif is required, which binds to the active zinc ion located at the bottom of the pocket, and (2) a large hydrophobic residue is necessary to occupy the penultimate position to the N-terminal glutamine. These two rules should be considered when designing and developing novel QC inhibitors regardless of the presence of an imidazole moiety.

    3.2. Other Chemicals

    Natural products are also a source of material for the discovery and development of novel QC inhibitors. The aggregation and cytotoxicity of pE-Aß and QC activity in vitro and in vivo, were all reduced/inhibited in the presence of oleuropein aglycone (OLE) (Figure 8), a natural phenol abundant in extra virgin olive oil. Memory and behavioral performance in aged TgCRND8 AD mice was improved significantly after OLE treatment.(147) Moreover, for the inhibitory effects of crude algal extracts on QC activity, three sulfolipids, for example, S1 shown in Figure 8, were identified as potential QC inhibitors using a reverse metabolomics technique including an activity-correlation analysis.(148) Sulfolipids could be thought of as a novel scaffold in which the sulfonate group might act as the important pharmacophore that binds to Zn2+. In another report, a series of apigenin derivatives modified at phenol-4′ (R1), C5-OH (R2), and C7-OH (R3) exhibited remarkable hQC inhibitory potency. For example, the IC50 value of compound A1 was ∼16.1 ± 2.0 μM (Figure 8).(149) An SAR analysis demonstrated that C7-OH was required for binding with Zn2+ and that C5-OH was favored, whereas phenol-4′ was tolerant for the inhibitory activity. So, new scaffolds and active compounds based on natural products could be the focus for the development of novel anti-AD agents targeting QC.
    Moreover, a most recent study identified novel strategies in the design of potent and highly selective QC inhibitors by employing hydrazides as the metal-binding warhead. The structural basis of hydrazide inhibition was illuminated by an X-ray structure analysis of human QC in a complex with a hydrazide-bearing peptide inhibitor and revealed a pentacoordinated Zn complex.(150)

    4. Efficiency Evaluation of QC Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Because of the crucial role of abnormally upregulated QC in the initiation of multiple diseases such as AD, inflammation, and cancer, by catalyzing the generation of pE-Aβ and pE-CCL2, QC could be supposed as a reasonable target for the future development of novel and useful pharmacological agents. As expected, the potency of a few QC inhibitors has been amply demonstrated both in vitro and in vivo.
    To explore new therapeutics, the application of QC inhibitors is gaining increasing attention for the treatment of AD. In mammalian cells, glutamine and glutamic acid cyclization were inhibited, and the toxicity of pE-Aβs was reduced notably in the presence of QC inhibitors.(151) The amyloidogenic processing of APP was blocked, and the generation of pE-Aβ3–40/42 was reduced by inhibiting QC activity.(152) An oral application of PBD150 reduced the generation of pE-Aβ3–42 and Aβx-40/42, diminished the formation of plaques in brains, reduced gliosis, and improved the performance in Tg2576 (B6/SJL, human APPsw695-transgene) and TASD-41 mice (C57/Bl6 hybrid) and in a new Drosophila model.(153) γ-Secretase activity was modulated, and the aggregation of pE-Aβ3–42 was lowered remarkably in the 5XFAD mice treated with a QC inhibitor.(154) In B6C3-Tg mice, treatment with DPCI-28 resulted in a dose-dependent decrease of QC activity and pE-Aβ3–42 aggregates in the hippocampus, cortex, and total brain. And a significant behavioral improvement in treated B6C3-Tg mice was observed compared with the mice in the control group.(136)
    More importantly, PQ912, the first oral QC inhibitor, is already in clinical trials for the treatment of AD. The randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single- and multiple-dose oral dose studies on the safety, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of PQ912 in healthy nonelderly and elderly volunteers confirmed that PQ912 is safe and well-tolerated.(133) The Phase I clinical trial of PQ912 was conducted in 2015. The Phase 2a study demonstrated that QC activity was inhibited significantly after the treatment of PQ912, which resulted in an average target occupancy of more than 90% and a significant improvement in the One Back test of the Neuropsychological Test Battery.(135) These results indicated the application of the QC inhibitor as a new agent for the prevention and treatment of AD.
    Liver inflammation is frequently characterized by the upregulation of CCL2 and other chemokine pathways. The effects of PQ529 and PBD150 on inflammation were evaluated in mouse models of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). It was found that circulating alanine aminotransferase, NAFLD activity score, the number of F4/80-positive macrophages, and liver fibrosis were all significantly reduced or attenuated after the treatment of QC inhibitors.(155) Monocyte and cell migration were both attenuated significantly in the presence of PBD150.(156) Monocyte infiltration was inhibited in inflammatory models such as thioglycollate-induced peritonitis, and atherosclerotic pathology was also attenuated in ApoE3*Leiden mice after the treatment of PQ50/PQ529. Therefore, the application of the QC inhibitor may present a new strategy for the treatment of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis and inflammatory diseases.
    Besides, the efficacy of two QC inhibitors, PBD155 and PQ529, was evaluated, and the onset of clinical symptoms of arthritis was significantly delayed in a mouse model of septic arthritis.(109) Treatment of QC inhibitors, for example, SEN177, slowed the pathology in cells, flies, and a zebrafish model of HD.(82) Inhibiting QC and iso-QC by PQ50 and PQ529 also attenuated an atherosclerotic pathology in accelerated atherosclerotic models.(87) These observations indicated that QC could also serve as a possible target for the treatment of these diseases.

    5. Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Because of the generation of pE-modified mediators catalyzed mainly by QC and the positive correlation between the upregulation of QC and the initiation of multiple diseases, identifying small molecule inhibitors of QC is becoming a promising therapeutic strategy to treat upregulated QC-related diseases. Over the past decades, a series of compounds carrying different scaffolds has been developed as potential QC inhibitors. The promising efficiency of some QC inhibitors in these diseases and conditions has been confirmed both in vitro and in vivo. However, there remain issues that need to be addressed. One major concern is the specificity of effects. Because pE is the N-terminus of numerous proteins essential to life, an overactivity of QC may result in widespread homeostatic disturbances that affect multiple areas of cellular biochemistry in a number of pathways and organs. Therefore, unpredictable side effects that may be inevitable, at least to some degree, should be noted and avoided in the process of inhibitor development. It is demonstrated that 11C-labeled PBD150 does not penetrate the BBB in mice.(157) This indicates that the anti-AD effects of the QC inhibitor in vivo may not be due to the direct central nervous system (CNS) effects. The possible underlying pathways or mechanisms of QC inhibitors require further investigation. In view of the difference between the roles of QC and that of iso-QC in different conditions, improved target selectivity and BBB penetrability are both essential for the discovery and evaluation of novel and clinically useful QC inhibitors.

    1. 1
      Azarkan, M.; Wintjens, R.; Looze, Y.; Baeyens-Volant, D. Detection of three wound-induced proteins in papaya latex. Phytochemistry 2004, 65, 525– 34,  DOI: 10.1016/j.phytochem.2003.12.006
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Detection of three wound-induced proteins in papaya latex
      Azarkan, Mohamed; Wintjens, Rene; Looze, Yvan; Baeyens-Volant, Danielle
      Phytochemistry (Elsevier) (2004), 65 (5), 525-534CODEN: PYTCAS; ISSN:0031-9422. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
      The effects of routine mech. wounding for latex collection from unripe fruits of the tropical Carica papaya tree were investigated. For that purpose, the protein compn. of three different latexes was analyzed. The first one, com. available, was provided in the form of a spray-dried powder, the second one was harvested from fully grown but unripe papaya fruits that are regularly tapped for latex prodn. and the last one, was obtained from similar fruits wounded for the first time. Repeated mech. wounding profoundly affected the protein content of the latex inducing, among others, activation of papain. Regularly tapped latexes also accumulated several low-mol.-wt. proteins not yet identified, as well as three proteins identified as a trypsin inhibitor, a class-II chitinase and a glutaminyl cyclase on the basis of their enzymic or inhibitory activities and chromatog. elution profiles. This latter was found here, for the first time, to be a wound-induced protein. The roles of these proteins in the plant defense mechanism are discussed.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhslehsLo%253D&md5=b1c6f5b612fc016601fbcba24be326c9
    2. 2
      Messer, M. Enzymatic cyclization of L-glutamine and L-glutaminyl peptides. Nature 1963, 197, 1299,  DOI: 10.1038/1971299a0
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Enzymic cyclization of L-glutamine and L-glutaminyl peptides
      Messer, Michael
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1963), 197 (), 1299CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
      At the optimum pH of 10, 1 mg. of the sol. fraction of crude papain (I) liberated 0.057 micromole NH3/min. from a 0.025M L-glutamine (II) soln. at 30°. Paper chromatography showed that II was converted to a ninhydrin-neg. compd. which had the same Rf as proline. D-Glutamine was not affected and I was made inactive by heating for 20 min. at 90°. Dialysis of I or pretreatment with iodoacetate or ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid had no effect and pure I and chymopapain were inactive. L-Glutaminyl dipeptides were deamidated and cyclized more rapidly and at a lower pH than II.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF3sXnsVCqtw%253D%253D&md5=a0fbeb450c6d1992be19930ff36f8176
    3. 3
      Bockers, T. M.; Kreutz, M. R.; Pohl, T. Glutaminyl-cyclase expression in the bovine/porcine hypothalamus and pituitary. J. Neuroendocrinol. 1995, 7, 445– 53,  DOI: 10.1111/j.1365-2826.1995.tb00780.x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Glutaminyl-cyclase expression in the bovine/porcine hypothalamus and pituitary
      Bockers T M; Kreutz M R; Pohl T
      Journal of neuroendocrinology (1995), 7 (6), 445-53 ISSN:0953-8194.
      The expression of the glutaminyl cyclase (QC), an enzyme responsible for the post-translational modification of N-terminal pyroglutamyl residues of neuropeptide precursors, was examined in bovine/porcine hypothalamic and pituitary tissue by means of immunocytochemistry and in situ hybridization. In the anterior pituitary a distinct pattern of QC immunoreactivity and mRNA expression was found associated exclusively with somatotrophs. In corticotrophs of the pars intermedia QC expression was undetectable, whereas a small portion of putative pars tuberalis cells in the rostral part of the pars distalis were heavily labelled. The neurointermediate lobe was devoid of signals for QC mRNA, but showed significant QC-immunoreactivity on secretory granules of axonal nerve endings. Also nuclei of the hypothalamus were found to be positive for QC-immunoreactivity. Intense labelling was observed in the nucleus supraopticus and nucleus paraventricularis. Staining of the nucleus periventricularis was found to be moderate, whereas no labelling of perikarya in the nucleus arcuatus, the preoptic area and the nucleus suprachiasmaticus was detectable. Moreover, varicose fibers stained positive for QC-immunoreactivity and could be identified in the main transport route from the hypothalamus to the pars neuronalis (tractus hypothalamo hypophysialis). These results suggest that the enzyme is transported via the same routes as its substrate/product to the median eminence or the neural lobe. Furthermore, the mapping of the cellular QC distribution reveals a strikingly distinctive expression pattern, that should be useful for the identification of yet undiscovered places of peptide synthesis and processing.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaK28%252FgvVSkuw%253D%253D&md5=623044c0c3d4e838cf9b833b04722f41
    4. 4
      Wang, Y. M.; Huang, K. F.; Tsai, I. H. Snake venom glutaminyl cyclases: purification, cloning, kinetic study, recombinant expression, and comparison with the human enzyme. Toxicon 2014, 86, 40– 50,  DOI: 10.1016/j.toxicon.2014.04.012
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Snake venom glutaminyl cyclases: Purification, cloning, kinetic study, recombinant expression, and comparison with the human enzyme
      Wang, Ying-Ming; Huang, Kai-Fa; Tsai, Inn-Ho
      Toxicon (2014), 86 (), 40-50CODEN: TOXIA6; ISSN:0041-0101. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Among various snake venom components, glutaminyl cyclase (vQC) is one of the least understood protein family and none of its members has been purified or characterized. Here we confirmed the presence of vQC activity in a wide spectrum of venom species via enzymic assay using a synthetic fluorogenic substrate. We have also cloned novel vQC cDNAs from seven species including Crotalus atrox. The results revealed more than 96% sequence similarities among vQCs and ∼75% sequence identities between vQCs and human secretory QC (hQC). The vQC glycoprotein of 43 kDa was isolated from C. atrox venom, and its N-terminal sequence was detd. The optimal pH range for vQC reaction was 7.5-8.0, and the enzymes were stable up to 50 °C. Similar to hQC, vQCs were substantially inactivated by 1 mM 1,10-phenanthroline but slightly affected by 20 mM EDTA, suggestive of a similar zinc-catalytic environment for these enzymes. Although their catalytic residues were highly conserved, vQCs were less susceptible to inhibition by synthetic imidazole derivs. which potently inhibited hQC. The 3D-models revealed that vQC and hQC structures display different surface charge distributions around the active sites, which might affect substrate and inhibitor binding affinities. The recombinant vQCs prepd. from Escherichia coli displayed weaker substrate binding affinities relative to the native vQCs, possibly due to the lack of glycosylation. The present report offers new structural and functional insights into vQCs and sheds light on the specificity differences between vQCs and hQC. Eight nucleotide sequences encoding the vQCs of Crotalus atrox, Micrurus fulvius, Cerrophidion godmani, Daboia russelii, Trimeresurus gracilis, Protobothrops mucrosquamatus, and Sistrurus catenatus tergeminus have been deposited in GenBank with the accession nos. JF979132-JF979139.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtVWqsLrE&md5=88cce226e13aea8f914edf63a094c2d8
    5. 5
      Vijayasarathy, M.; Basheer, S. M.; Balaram, P. Cone snail glutaminyl cyclase sequences from transcriptomic analysis and mass spectrometric characterization of two pyroglutamyl conotoxins. J. Proteome Res. 2018, 17, 2695– 2703,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jproteome.8b00132
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Cone Snail Glutaminyl Cyclase Sequences from Transcriptomic Analysis and Mass Spectrometric Characterization of Two Pyroglutamyl Conotoxins
      Vijayasarathy Marimuthu; Basheer Soorej M; Balaram Padmanabhan; Vijayasarathy Marimuthu; Balaram Padmanabhan; Basheer Soorej M
      Journal of proteome research (2018), 17 (8), 2695-2703 ISSN:.
      The post-translational modification of N-terminal glutamine (Q) to a pyroglutamyl (Z) residue is observed in the conotoxins produced by marine cone snails. This conversion requires the action of the enzyme glutaminyl cyclase (QC). Four complete QC sequences from the species C. araneosus, C. frigidus, C. litteratus, and C. monile and two partial sequences from C. amadis and C. miles have been obtained by analysis of transcriptomic data. Comparisons with mammalian enzyme sequences establish a high level of identity and complete conservation of functional active site residues, including a cluster of hydrogen-bonded acidic side chains. Mass spectrometric analysis of crude venom samples coupled to conotoxin precursor protein sequences obtained from transcriptomic data establishes the presence of pyroglutamyl conotoxins in the venom of C. frigidus and C. amadis. The C. frigidus peptide belongs to the M superfamily, with cysteine framework III, whereas the C. amadis peptide belongs to the divergent superfamily with cysteine framework VI/VII. Additionally, gamma carboxylation of glutamic acid and hydroxylation of proline are observed in the C. frigidus peptide. Mass spectral data are available via ProteomeXchange with identifier PXD009006.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3c%252Fit1Khtw%253D%253D&md5=6e236da3ba3997cea4ed84020453e4d8
    6. 6
      Sykes, P. A.; Watson, S. J.; Temple, J. S.; Bateman, R. J. Evidence for tissue-specific forms of glutaminyl cyclase. FEBS Lett. 1999, 455, 159– 61,  DOI: 10.1016/S0014-5793(99)00872-8
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Evidence for tissue-specific forms of glutaminyl cyclase
      Sykes, Paul A.; Watson, Stephanie J.; Temple, Jeffrey S.; Bateman, Robert C., Jr.
      FEBS Letters (1999), 455 (1,2), 159-161CODEN: FEBLAL; ISSN:0014-5793. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
      Glutaminyl cyclase (QC) is responsible for the presence of pyroglutamyl residues in many neuroendocrine peptides. An examn. of the bovine tissue distribution of QC immunoreactivity, enzyme activity, and mRNA confirmed that QC was abundant in brain and pituitary by all three measures. However, enzymic activity was considerably more widespread than either immunoreactivity or mRNA, suggesting multiple enzyme forms. Partially purified QC from bovine spleen differed significantly from the known bovine pituitary QC in phys. and catalytic properties. We propose that this form of glutaminyl cyclase plays a role in the posttranslational processing of constitutively secreted pGlu-contg. proteins.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXltFWnur0%253D&md5=6a10132cc48d48f352b96c0d531d25e3
    7. 7
      Huang, W. L.; Wang, Y. R.; Ko, T. P.; Chia, C. Y.; Huang, K. F.; Wang, A. H. Crystal structure and functional analysis of the glutaminyl cyclase from Xanthomonas campestris. J. Mol. Biol. 2010, 401, 374– 88,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jmb.2010.06.012
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Crystal Structure and Functional Analysis of the Glutaminyl Cyclase from Xanthomonas campestris
      Huang, Wei-Lin; Wang, Yu-Ruei; Ko, Tzu-Ping; Chia, Cho-Yun; Huang, Kai-Fa; Wang, Andrew H.-J.
      Journal of Molecular Biology (2010), 401 (3), 374-388CODEN: JMOBAK; ISSN:0022-2836. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Glutaminyl cyclases (QCs) (EC 2.3.2.5) catalyze the formation of pyroglutamate (pGlu) at the N-terminus of many proteins and peptides, a crit. step for the maturation of these bioactive mols. Proteins having QC activity have been identified in animals and plants, but not in bacteria. Here, we report the first bacterial QC from the plant pathogen Xanthomonas campestris (Xc). The crystal structure of the enzyme was solved and refined to 1.44-Å resoln. The structure shows a five-bladed β-propeller and exhibits a scaffold similar to that of papaya QC (pQC), but with some sequence deletions and conformational changes. In contrast to the pQC structure, the active site of XcQC has a wider substrate-binding pocket, but its accessibility is modulated by a protruding loop acting as a flap. Enzyme activity analyses showed that the wild-type XcQC possesses only 3% QC activity compared to that of pQC. Superposition of those two structures revealed that an active-site glutamine residue in pQC is substituted by a glutamate (Glu45) in XcQC, although position 45 is a glutamine in most bacterial QC sequences. The E45Q mutation increased the QC activity by an order of magnitude, but the mutation E45A led to a drop in the enzyme activity, indicating the crit. catalytic role of this residue. Further mutagenesis studies support the catalytic role of Glu89 as proposed previously and confirm the importance of several conserved amino acids around the substrate-binding pocket. XcQC was shown to be weakly resistant to guanidine hydrochloride, extreme pH, and heat denaturations, in contrast to the extremely high stability of pQC, despite their similar scaffold. On the basis of structure comparison, the low stability of XcQC may be attributed to the absence of both a disulfide linkage and some hydrogen bonds in the closure of β-propeller structure. These results significantly improve our understanding of the catalytic mechanism and extreme stability of type I QCs, which will be useful in further applications of QC enzymes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXpsFOnsLk%253D&md5=da272da9d25ebcc7254e8a565eef6f91
    8. 8
      Oberg, K. A.; Ruysschaert, J. M.; Azarkan, M.; Smolders, N.; Zerhouni, S.; Wintjens, R.; Amrani, A.; Looze, Y. Papaya glutamine cyclase, a plant enzyme highly resistant to proteolysis, adopts an all-beta conformation. Eur. J. Biochem. 1998, 258, 214– 22,  DOI: 10.1046/j.1432-1327.1998.2580214.x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Papaya glutamine cyclase, a plant enzyme highly resistant to proteolysis, adopts an all-β conformation
      Oberg, Keith A.; Ruysschaert, Jean-Marie; Azarkan, Mohamed; Smolders, Nicole; Zerhouni, Samira; Wintjens, Rene; Amrani, Amina; Looze, Yvan
      European Journal of Biochemistry (1998), 258 (1), 214-222CODEN: EJBCAI; ISSN:0014-2956. (Springer-Verlag)
      Glutamine cyclase (EC 2.3.2.5) (I) catalyzes the conversion of L-glutaminyl-peptides into 5-oxoprolyl-peptides with the concomitant liberation of NH3. Here, the biophys. characterization of I present in the laticiferous cells of Carica papaya is reported. After purifn. to near homogeneity, I was subjected to limited proteolysis and found to exhibit a high resistance to degrdn. and nicking. The structural reasons for this property were examd. using CD and IR spectroscopies. By combining the analyses of the IR and CD spectra of papaya I, its susceptibility to proteolysis, and its H-D exchange characteristics, it was concluded that I contains extensive β-sheet structure and is likely to have only short immobile loops connecting its β-strands.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXnsFCnsbk%253D&md5=460130fc378466d6b833b6f6274202ca
    9. 9
      Wintjens, R.; Belrhali, H.; Clantin, B.; Azarkan, M.; Bompard, C.; Baeyens-Volant, D.; Looze, Y.; Villeret, V. Crystal structure of papaya glutaminyl cyclase, an archetype for plant and bacterial glutaminyl cyclases. J. Mol. Biol. 2006, 357, 457– 70,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jmb.2005.12.029
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Crystal Structure of Papaya Glutaminyl Cyclase, an Archetype for Plant and Bacterial Glutaminyl Cyclases
      Wintjens, Rene; Belrhali, Hassan; Clantin, Bernard; Azarkan, Mohamed; Bompard, Coralie; Baeyens-Volant, Danielle; Looze, Yvan; Villeret, Vincent
      Journal of Molecular Biology (2006), 357 (2), 457-470CODEN: JMOBAK; ISSN:0022-2836. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Glutaminyl cyclases (QCs) (E.C. 2.3.2.5) catalyze the intramol. cyclization of protein N-terminal glutamine residues into pyroglutamic acid with the concomitant liberation of ammonia. QCs may be classified in two groups contg., resp., the mammalian enzymes, and the enzymes from plants, bacteria, and parasites. The crystal structure of the QC from the latex of Carica papaya (PQC) has been detd. at 1.7 Å resoln. The structure was solved by the single wavelength anomalous diffraction technique using sulfur and zinc as anomalous scatterers. The enzyme folds into a five-bladed β-propeller, with two addnl. α-helixes and one β hairpin. The propeller closure is achieved via an original mol. velcro, which links the last two blades into a large eight stranded β-sheet. The zinc ion present in the PQC is bound via an octahedral coordination into an elongated cavity located along the pseudo 5-fold axis of the β-propeller fold. This zinc ion presumably plays a structural role and may contribute to the exceptional stability of PQC, along with an extended hydrophobic packing, the absence of long loops, the three-joint mol. velcro and the overall folding itself. Multiple sequence alignments combined with structural analyses have allowed us to tentatively locate the active site, which is filled in the crystal structure either by a Tris mol. or an acetate ion. These analyses are further supported by the exptl. evidence that Tris is a competitive inhibitor of PQC. The active site is located at the C-terminal entrance of the PQC central tunnel. W83, W110, W169, Q24, E69, N155, K225, F22 and F67 are highly conserved residues in the C-terminal entrance, and their putative role in catalysis is discussed. The PQC structure is representative of the plants, bacterial and parasite enzymes and contrasts with that of mammalian enzymes, that may possibly share a conserved scaffold of the bacterial aminopeptidase.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XitVGhsbc%253D&md5=7223abf4574b696d2a18286e962130d4
    10. 10
      Pohl, T.; Zimmer, M.; Mugele, K.; Spiess, J. Primary structure and functional expression of a glutaminyl cyclase. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991, 88, 10059– 63,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.88.22.10059
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Primary structure and functional expression of a glutaminyl cyclase
      Pohl, Thomas; Zimmer, Michael; Mugele, Katrin; Spiess, Joachim
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1991), 88 (22), 10059-63CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
      A glutaminyl cyclase (QC) that is probably involved in the biosynthesis of pyroglutamyl peptides such as gonadotropin-releasing hormone and TSH-releasing hormone has been purified to homogeneity from bovine anterior pituitary. On the basis of N-terminal sequence anal., a 2088-base-pair cDNA clone was isolated from a bovine anterior pituitary library. From the nucleotide sequence of this clone, the primary structure of a 330-residue protein and a preceding 31-residue prepropeptide sequence was deduced. By transfection of COS-7 monkey cells with a QC cDNA/pCDM8 vector construct, QC activity was expressed. Hybridization with mRNAs of various bovine tissues revealed expression of QC mainly in brain tissue.

      Schilling, S.; Hoffmann, T.; Rosche, F.; Manhart, S.; Wasternack, C.; Demuth, H. U. Heterologous expression and characterization of human glutaminyl cyclase: evidence for a disulfide bond with importance for catalytic activity. Biochemistry 2002, 41, 10849– 57,  DOI: 10.1021/bi0260381
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Heterologous Expression and Characterization of Human Glutaminyl Cyclase: Evidence for a Disulfide Bond with Importance for Catalytic Activity
      Schilling, Stephan; Hoffmann, Torsten; Rosche, Fred; Manhart, Susanne; Wasternack, Claus; Demuth, Hans-Ulrich
      Biochemistry (2002), 41 (35), 10849-10857CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960. (American Chemical Society)
      Glutaminyl cyclase (QC, EC 2.3.2.5) catalyzes the formation of pyroglutamate residues from glutamine at the N-terminus of peptides and proteins. In the current study, human QC was functionally expressed in the secretory pathway of Pichia pastoris, yielding milligram quantities after purifn. from the supernatant of a 5 L fermn. Initial characterization studies of the recombinant QC using MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry revealed correct proteolytic processing and N-glycosylation at both potential sites with similar 2 kDa extensions. CD spectral anal. indicated a high α-helical content, which contrasts with plant QC from Carica papaya. The kinetic parameters for conversion of H-Gln-Tyr-Ala-OH by recombinant human QC were almost identical to those previously reported for purified bovine pituitary QC. However, the results obtained for conversion of H-Gln-Gln-OH, H-Gln-NH2, and H-Gln-AMC were found to be contradictory to previous studies on human QC expressed intracellularly in E. coli. Expression of QC in E. coli showed that approx. 50% of the protein did not contain a disulfide bond that is present in the entire QC expressed in P. pastoris. Further, the enzyme was consistently inactivated by treatment with 15 mM DTT, whereas deglycosylation had no effect on enzymic activity. Anal. of the fluorescence spectra of the native, reduced, and unfolded human QC point to a conformational change of the protein upon treatment with DTT. In terms of the different enzymic properties, the consequences of QC expression in different environments are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XlvFSmtro%253D&md5=c7d449a36576aec362a0b17bb7de2d4c
    12. 12
      Schilling, S.; Manhart, S.; Hoffmann, T.; Ludwig, H. H.; Wasternack, C.; Demuth, H. U. Substrate specificity of glutaminyl cyclases from plants and animals. Biol. Chem. 2003, 384, 1583– 92,  DOI: 10.1515/BC.2003.175
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Substrate specificity of glutaminyl cyclases from plants and animals
      Schilling, Stephan; Manhart, Susanne; Hoffmann, Torsten; Ludwig, Hans-henning; Wasternack, Claus; Demuth, Hans-ulrich
      Biological Chemistry (2003), 384 (12), 1583-1592CODEN: BICHF3; ISSN:1431-6730. (Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co. KG)
      Glutaminyl cyclases (QC) catalyze the intramol. cyclization of N-terminal glutamine residues of peptides and proteins. For a comparison of the substrate specificity of human and papaya QC enzymes, a novel continuous assay was established by adapting an existing discontinuous method. Specificity consts. (kcat/Km) of dipeptides and dipeptide surrogates were higher for plant QC, whereas the selectivity for oligopeptides was similar for both enzymes. However, only the specificity consts. of mammalian QC were dependent on size and compn. of the substrates. Specificity consts. of both enzymes were equally pH-dependent in the acidic pH-region, revealing a pKa value identical to the pKa of the substrate, suggesting similarities in the substrate conversion mode. Accordingly, both QCs converted the L-βhomoglutaminyl residue in the peptide H-βhomoGln-Phe-Lys-Arg-Leu-Ala-NH2 and the glutaminyl residues of the branched peptide H-Gln-Lys(Gln)-Arg-Leu-Ala-NH2 as well as the partially cyclized peptide H-Gln-cyclo(Nε-Lys-Arg-Pro-Ala-Gly-Phe). In contrast, only QC from C. papaya was able to cyclize a methylated glutamine residue, while this compd. did not even inhibit human QC-catalysis, suggesting distinct substrate recognition pattern. The conversion of the potential physiol. substrates [Gln1]-gastrin, [Gln1]-neurotensin and [Gln1]-fertilization promoting peptide indicates that human QC may play a key role in posttranslational modification of most if not all pGlu-contg. hormones.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtVSksQ%253D%253D&md5=3e011093800699f46513a309b29647c8
    13. 13
      Cynis, H.; Rahfeld, J. U.; Stephan, A.; Kehlen, A.; Koch, B.; Wermann, M.; Demuth, H. U.; Schilling, S. Isolation of an isoenzyme of human glutaminyl cyclase: retention in the Golgi complex suggests involvement in the protein maturation machinery. J. Mol. Biol. 2008, 379, 966– 80,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jmb.2008.03.078
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Isolation of an Isoenzyme of Human Glutaminyl Cyclase: Retention in the Golgi Complex Suggests Involvement in the Protein Maturation Machinery
      Cynis, Holger; Rahfeld, Jens-Ulrich; Stephan, Anett; Kehlen, Astrid; Koch, Birgit; Wermann, Michael; Demuth, Hans-Ulrich; Schilling, Stephan
      Journal of Molecular Biology (2008), 379 (5), 966-980CODEN: JMOBAK; ISSN:0022-2836. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Mammalian glutaminyl cyclase isoenzymes (isoQCs) were identified. The anal. of the primary structure of human isoQC (h-isoQC) revealed conservation of the zinc-binding motif of the human QC (hQC). In contrast to hQC, h-isoQC carries an N-terminal signal anchor. The cDNAs of human and murine isoQCs were isolated and h-isoQC, lacking the N-terminal signal anchor and the short cytosolic tail, was expressed as a fusion protein in Escherichia coli. h-isoQC exhibits 10-fold lower activity compared to hQC. Similar to hQC, h-isoQC was competitively inhibited by imidazoles and cysteamines. Inactivation by metal chelators suggests a conserved metal-dependent catalytic mechanism of both isoenzymes. A comparison of the expression pattern of m-isoQC and murine QC revealed ubiquitous expression of both enzymes. However, murine QC transcript formation was higher in neuronal tissue, whereas the amt. of m-isoQC transcripts did not vary significantly between different organs. h-isoQC was exclusively localized within the Golgi complex, obviously retained by the N-terminus. Similar resident enzymes of the Golgi complex are the glycosyltransferases. Golgi app. retention implies a "housekeeping" protein maturation machinery conducting glycosylation and pyroglutamyl formation. For these enzymes, apparently similar strategies evolved to retain the proteins in the Golgi complex.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXmsFKqtL4%253D&md5=707e10bf9a6f5b84ac8c455dd86ec4cf
